<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 306, 220, 321]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 358, 344]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1 (P1)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 460, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 448, 787, 465]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 325, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 540, 285, 555]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 555, 910, 586]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 585, 593, 600]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 600, 606, 615]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 630, 609, 645]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 645, 756, 660]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 660, 440, 676]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
An arithmetic progression has first term \(-12\) and common difference 6. The sum of the first \(n\) terms exceeds 3000. Calculate the least possible value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 92, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(a\) for which the curve \(y = - \frac{2}{x}\) and the straight line \(y = ax + 3a\) meet at two distinct points.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 98, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 94, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 78, 156, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 72, 653, 102]]<|/det|>
Find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(\frac{2}{x} - 3x\right)^6\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 79, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 520, 186, 537]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 72, 653, 102]]<|/det|>
Find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(\frac{2}{x} - 3x\right)^6\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 78, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 520, 816, 541]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(a\) for which there is no term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 549, 584, 584]]<|/det|>
\[(1 + ax^{2})\left(\frac{2}{x} -3x\right)^{6}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 559, 920, 578]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 77, 92, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
The function f is such that \(\mathrm{f}(x) = (2x - 1)^{\frac{3}{2}} - 6x\) for \(\frac{1}{2} < x < k\), where \(k\) is a constant. Find the largest value of \(k\) for which f is a decreasing function.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 92, 920, 110]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 76, 156, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 72, 915, 107]]<|/det|>
Show that the equation \(\frac{\cos \theta + 4}{\sin \theta + 1} + 5 \sin \theta - 5 = 0\) may be expressed as \(5 \cos^2 \theta - \cos \theta - 4 = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 100, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 77, 153, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 72, 722, 102]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(\frac{\cos \theta + 4}{\sin \theta + 1} + 5 \sin \theta - 5 = 0\) for \(0^\circ \leqslant \theta \leqslant 360^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 77, 920, 96]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 73, 410, 92]]<|/det|>
The functions f and g are defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 100, 601, 133]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \frac{2}{x^{2} - 1}\mathrm{for} x< -1,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 134, 584, 153]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{g}(x) = x^{2} + 1\mathrm{for} x > 0.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 175, 156, 193]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 175, 400, 193]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 175, 920, 193]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 156, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 390, 91]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\mathrm{gf}(x) = 5\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 84, 655, 225]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 243, 920, 295]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a rectangle \(ABCD\) in which \(AB = 5\) units and \(BC = 3\) units. Point \(P\) lies on \(DC\) and \(AP\) is an arc of a circle with centre \(B\). Point \(Q\) lies on \(DC\) and \(AQ\) is an arc of a circle with centre \(D\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 305, 153, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 305, 698, 324]]<|/det|>
Show that angle \(ABP = 0.6435\) radians, correct to 4 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 306, 920, 324]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 609, 186, 626]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 609, 551, 626]]<|/det|>
Calculate the areas of the sectors \(BAP\) and \(DAQ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 609, 920, 626]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 84, 660, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 275, 910, 295]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows parts of the graphs of \(y = 3 - 2x\) and \(y = 4 - 3\sqrt{x}\) intersecting at points \(A\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 307, 156, 325]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 306, 551, 325]]<|/det|>
Find by calculation the \(x\)-coordinates of \(A\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 307, 920, 325]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 695, 92]]<|/det|>
Find, showing all necessary working, the area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 767, 94]]<|/det|>
Relative to an origin \(O\), the position vectors of the points \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\) are given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 100, 712, 147]]<|/det|>
\[\overrightarrow{OA} = \left( \begin{array}{c}8\\ -6\\ 5 \end{array} \right), \quad \overrightarrow{OB} = \left( \begin{array}{c} -10\\ 3\\ -13 \end{array} \right) \quad \text{and} \quad \overrightarrow{OC} = \left( \begin{array}{c}2\\ -3\\ -1 \end{array} \right).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 158, 920, 196]]<|/det|>
A fourth point, \(D\), is such that the magnitudes \(|\overrightarrow{AB}|\), \(|\overrightarrow{BC}|\) and \(|\overrightarrow{CD}|\) are the first, second and third terms respectively of a geometric progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 210, 154, 229]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 208, 500, 230]]<|/det|>
Find the magnitudes \(|\overrightarrow{AB}|\), \(|\overrightarrow{BC}|\) and \(|\overrightarrow{CD}|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 211, 920, 230]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Given that \(D\) is a point lying on the line through \(B\) and \(C\), find the two possible position vectors of the point \(D\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) and it is given that \(\mathrm{f}'(x) = ax^2 + bx\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are positive constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 104, 154, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(a\) and \(b\), the non-zero value of \(x\) for which the curve has a stationary point and determine, showing all necessary working, the nature of the stationary point. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
It is now given that the curve has a stationary point at \((-2, -3)\) and that the gradient of the curve at \(x = 1\) is 9. Find \(\mathrm{f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 84, 730, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 252, 858, 275]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = (x - 1)^{\frac{1}{2}}\) and points \(A\) (1, 0) and \(B\) (5, 2) lying on the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 286, 156, 304]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 286, 764, 304]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the line \(AB\), giving your answer in the form \(y = mx + c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 286, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 528, 151, 546]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 528, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
Find, showing all necessary working, the equation of the tangent to the curve which is parallel to \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 541, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
